pros: New grad program hires into exciting units. High acuity patients are challenging in a way I love. Nursing staff are very smart and competent.

Even if Swedish was a good work environment, the money alone makes it impossible to stay afloat and save for a house and other basic necessities in the long term. I can barely pay 1 bedroom apartment rent. Unfortunately, you will never have the staff, equipment, or support you need to provide your patients with care they deserve. Swedish has been hit by a mass exodus following poor treatment of staff, medieval level pay, and management that is tone-deaf at best, and completely incompetent at worst. When doctors try to intervene on the behalf of nurses, they are told to “stay in their lanes.” Management asks what will keep nursing staff? Nurses all say we need fair compensation, and it falls on deaf ears. I get texts about 3 times a day asking to come in for overtime because we’re so short.

review_title: Good in the right department; a nightmare in the wrong one
pros: Swedish provides good insurance with low premiums. Education can be subsidized if it meets certain criteria, including non-nursing bachelors and graduate programs. Some departments have wonderful cultures (though not many).
cons:
In one word, management. Management demonstrates complete neglect of qualitative evidence and anecdotes that contextualize the quantitative data upon which they base their decisions. So, they understand the "what" behind the data, and fail at extrapolating the "why" time and time again. Staff is constantly harassed by management and threatened without being heard. Experienced staff has left en masse over the past 3 years. The new staff - mainly new grads - and aggressive management have created a toxic culture and an unsafe work environment in many departments.

Swedish was also extremely stingy in the most recent contract negotiations. Overall cost of living in Seattle has gone up 6% in the past year alone in an area where most employees earn less than the average salary in the area, while our raises amount to around 2%. We are being paid less to do the same job as time goes by. Shift differentials and standby pay also suck.

Furthermore, Swedish created two costly, diversity-related C-suite positions without realizing meaningful change for the disadvantaged employees and patients they sought to help. I see a lot of politically-driven e-mails, superficial partnerships with little substance (i.e. the partnership with Meharry SOM), and absolutely no real action. Maria Shands and Dr. Nwando Anyaoku, I'm looking at you.

pros: The nurses are all good people. I had no issues with the team I was a part of.

review_title: Foundation-specific: Malicious leadership creating unsustainable working environment
pros: Friendly coworkers and okay benefits. Three weeks of PTO.
cons:
This review pertains specifically to the Swedish Foundation, which operates closely with but separate from Swedish. 

Recent changes in leadership have exacerbated an existing problem with cliquish middle management. What was once a place of creativity and collaboration has, since these changes, very quickly become an environment where fear is the top motivator, and no one feels free to speak up and express concerns for fear of retaliation.

In response to the most recent employee engagement survey indicating that compensation was an area for improvement, middle management treated this concern with scorn, sometimes outright laughter. Some employees rely on housing assistance, while multiple middle and upper managers drive luxury cars, carry designer handbags, and live in multi-million dollar homes. The callousness and out-of-touch-ness in their response to employee concerns was disappointing.

Additionally, when some female employees were promoted, their new salaries were still less than male employees at the same level. Employees of color have been hired at lower levels (in terms of title and pay) than white employees, despite having comparable experience.

Flexible work arrangements made before recent leadership changes will not be honored, and discussion and negotiation are not on the table. Employees have been let go rather than even simply discuss compromise.

Workers have been put on performance improvement plans (whose terms ended in termination) despite having average and above average KPIs, including dollars raised. When asked for justification and explanation, only vague and unverifiable claims were made. 

Upper management told employees that they would be in Tuesday-Thursday and had employees sign a contract stating that they would be in office three days per week as well. However, a week or two after this contract, upper management visited the office and found that most employees were working from home on that Friday (having come in to the office Tuesday-Thursday). The leadership team then changed the expectation to Tuesday-Thursday and every other Friday in office, because they thought that an empty office on Friday "looked bad." 

Leadership has also engaged in ethically bad and legally dubious practices by declaring all employees "essential workers" so that they can demand in-office work. They have also engaged in retaliation and demanded resignations. 

Philanthropy has a serious turnover problem. In an industry where the average tenure in a job is 1.5 years, Swedish had long beaten this curve. Many employees have been here 5 or more years. That is unlikely to continue with these recent changes. Multiple employees have already left, and more are actively looking for jobs. 

It doesn't matter how hard you work or how much money you raise. Your job is dependent upon you kissing up to the right people. Prospective employees beware.

job_title: Registered Nurse, Critical Care in Seattle, WA
pros: Excellent onboarding experience with great relocation package before I oriented.  Great staff and ancillary support.  Incredible critical care competency exam to assess my current knowledge and deficits.  If you can master Swedish's critical care exam, you are well on your way in having baseline knowledge to sit for AACN's CCRN certification.  This exam surpassed the BKAT (Basic Knowledge Assessment Tool for ICU).  Excellent pay and benefits with great caregiver support.  Scheduling is fair and equitable.  Unionized with clear contract language.  I have yet to use my back like I did at other health care organizations.  This institution does everything possible to protect nurses' backs.  Balanced skill set between the nurses while working and everyone is eager to help. Supportive education to excel in learning new critical care concepts.  Facilitate evidence based practice and up to date resources in their standards.  Accreditation and certification is through the DNV-GL versus The Joint Commission.  DNV-GL surveyors are more collaborative and foster dialogue that is aimed to improve the system.  Nurses can apply critical thinking skills unlike academic medical centers where residents dictate care and you wait for their order.  A nice balance of seasoned nurses
cons: No all night food venues for night shifters. Bring your lunch!  Attrition.  Nursing is hard but given the nursing shortage and many younger nurses leaving to become APNs.  Its like every ICU in the nation, which seems to be a revolving door of nursing staff.

pros: Architecturally beautiful, new, green built facility.  Was once a wonderful place to work.
cons: Inconsistent standards between units with regards to CNA per patient, CNA tasks (ie vital signs, bathing, I/O's etc). Very poor overall sense of unity within facility. Food for patients often takes over an hour to arrive, and is often not what patient ordered, missing items.  Staff and families do not have food onsite or within walking distance, unless ordering from room service.  Staff not allowed to order from room service until after 2 pm.  Onsite cafeteria only open till 2 pm Monday thru Friday and not at all on weekends.  Often food runs out before 2 pm.  No break nurse provided, nurses take on 8-10 patients during day and 8-12 patients at night during "break-buddy" lunch.  Frequent policy changes that do not extend to all campuses.

pros: As soon as I started working here, I felt much better about being a CNA. My last hospital (VM) made me feel like a worker bee. I was often talked down to and called upon to do simple tasks that anyone (especially a nurse) could perform, but because I'm a CNA, no one need be bothered with such a thing. At Swedish, you are among peers. There is a level of respect among staff here that is hard to find, you're recognized for the work you put in rather than the nature of the work you do.
cons: We're often short staffed, at times I feel like I'm in a nursing home again. Tonight, I have 15 patients.

pros: Competitive pay, promote and support employee advancement. The downtown facilities offer a very diverse patient population, exposure to a wide variety of pathologies/conditions, level 3 medical facility means more exposure to complicated cases, and a fast paced environment. All these things mean a great amount of experience in a relatively small amount of time when compared with outlying facilities within other healthcare systems or even Swedish itself.
cons:
Swedish has expanded too quickly, pouring an excess amount of money into new facilities and takeovers. The former has caused cannibalization of its own market with respect to downtown facilities. The latter has caused Swedish to hemorrhage money out of the three new facilities with the end result being significant cuts to staff, benefits, and prospective wages across all campuses.

If you seek stability in the short term, this is not the place to take a job/career as the financial turmoil has yet to equalize. The focus has turned to the bottom line rather than effective and safe patient care. All of these changes have begun within the last 2 years.

review_title: (Edmonds) Excellent hospital with room for improvement!
job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Edmonds, WA
pros: Excellent work culture! Everyone is nice and I love how there is no "power distance". Which is not speaking up due to your ranking (i.e. nurses aides not being able to correct a nurse) and using your experience to speak up and contribute regardless of your job title. Innovation is what makes a work environment excellent and the fact that everyone can contribute and the environment encourages it is amazing. I work with amazing people there is not a lot of extra fluff (aka drama). Everyone works as a team! Literally communication within every department is seamless. I needed to see the staffing department and employee health about something and they all knew I was coming which made for easy exchange of information. I love using EPIC to chart! Excellent pay! Great benefits! Free parking. Reimbursement for continuing education.
cons: High patient to aide ratio. 13:1 however I don't do vitals. Wish there was another aide for assistance but it's not a big deal.

pros: Great co-workers, patient centered care, willingness of everyone to chip in and help. Resources available if you have the right connections and know how to work the many layers of middle management red tape.
cons: Very weak leadership, most are nurse managers who are trying to run a multi-billion dollar operation. Way too much emphasis on meeting arbitrary goals for 'team building' programs rather than operational needs. Many middle and upper managers who won't roll up their sleeves and pitch in. Promotions often based on 'who you know' rather than 'what you know'. I had far more education and experience than the Administrator 2 steps above me. There ARE many layoffs and firings occurring 'under the radar' due to declining reimbursement rates and need to finance billion-dollar First Hill expansion project.

pros: Ballard clinic has the BEST doctors to work for. Great patients !  Some very innovative physicians that welcome change.
cons: Awful work/life balance. Corporate management is all about the money(making it), some decisions are NOT patient friendly(like the decision to discontinue carrying patient samples).

review_title: If you want to move up, you have to fight for it
pros: Big company so lots of learning opportunities, can move to other departments if you want to do something new but don't expect any handouts.  Flex hours are a plus and being downtown is great.  There are people here who will help you grow and move up but you have to carefully identify them.
cons: Non-profit healthcare doesn't pay great.  The benefits are slowly being reduced, for working in healthcare the health insurance is really poor, high deductible.  Nepotism/favoritism is a serious problem.  Many promotions are based on who they know, not what they know, making everyone else's job difficult because they can't keep up.

review_title: Best Place to Work! 2 thumbs up
pros: The benefits are great! The community is awesome and the staff is constantly working with the mission and values in mind. We all love our patients, and their families. I believe that Swedish employees truely love what we do and making an impact on the patients and their families when they come here. This has been the BEST employer I have ever worked for. Most of the leadership has been amazing to work with, and there are tons of room to grow and advance.
cons: I have been thru 2 or 3 scary layoffs in the last 7.5 years of being here. It's really scary NOT knowing whether or not you will have a job each day or if they have eliminated your role/department.

pros: I work at the Swedish Cancer Institue outpatient treatment center. I have been working here for at least a year. The nurse managers, charge nurses, pharmacy staff, and all coworkers are very friendly and great to work with. The nurses can take up to one hour of lunch break for a 9-hour shift. There are many inservices and many opportunities to learn at work, including newly approved medications, bone marrow transplant care, and best nursing practice. The schedule is flexible and sometimes nurses can be allowed to leave work early if it is not busy. Charge nurses and nurse manages try best to accommodate work schedule preferences.
cons: The Institue is growing and expanding. The facility has been getting renovated to improve patient experience. The flow of patient care can sometimes be affected. The staff tries best to provide positive patient experiences regardlessly.

pros: Support staff is great and most really look out for one another.
cons: Coorporate executives should not be involved with something that should stay under management level when it comes to dealing with staff and clinic issues. Management should be given the necessary tools and training to deal with issues within their departments. 'Strings being pulled by Coorporate should be cut and power should be given to management to deal with their departments appropriately and should be there for advice or 'last option'. - Most departments seem like Doctors to run the show and management has no say. Too chaotic. It would be better if management and doctors worked together instead of against each other and Coorporate was there only for advice and direction, not directly involved with issues that can be resolved within departments.

pros:
Great co-workers and patients for the overall majority.
Neuroscience department has amazing management.
The doctors are great.
cons:
Swedish's financial crisis has increased layoffs.
Our department was promised a bonus if we met outrageous goals which we did in 2011. We did not receive the bonus due to the financial crisis which I am fine with as long as people keep their jobs. But they did not announce this until 2 days before our paychecks were issued and this was during the Christmas season. On top of this they announced it the same time to management so they had no time to prepare for their staffs inevitable upset.
The insurance change which causes staff to spend more time on the computer by forcing them to log activity levels etc. A little silly really.

pros:
Being a supervisor at the Swedish Medical Group for the last 4 years, I was taught by my leadership team how to be a good leader. By following Swedish Core Values: 1.) Patient Center Care and Service, 2.) Respect, Caring and Compassion, 3.) Continuous learning, 4.) Leadership.
The supervisors are the best to handle patient's accounts with diligence for the best of the patient. This is the reason why my provider still with Swedish Physicians, even I do not work anymore with Swedish.
I am a Swedish Boy, and I highly recommend Swedish for your next employer. If you like to work hard and make a difference, then Swedish is the right choice for you.
cons: After 12 years of working with Swedish Medical Group, I can not find any Cons!

pros: Good salary (Nursing union membership- optional) and excellent benefits.  Unfortunately, a high degree of nursing turnover.
cons: Management drags it’s feet in response to problems, especially Nursing Care and staffing ratios.  Garnered major bad publicity last year regarding a now disgraced and public departure of a  physician and his surgery practices.   Death of patient due to negligence.  The unwanted publicity resulted in the CEO resigning along with numerous department heads and physicians.   This information was reported by The Seattle Times newspaper.

pros: Swedish is committed to quality patient care, and is well known in the community for being a top health care choice.
cons: There is so much turnover, and Stewardship is stingy about letting departments fill vacancies and hire staff. Everyone is completely  bombarded and overworked, except for execs (naturally). Upper management is completely self-interested and doesn't fight the good fight for the staff on their respective teams. My philosophy has become grin and bear it as long as I can.

pros: My campus had a Starbucks!
cons: Where to start… managers in Neuroscience are ridiculous and out of control. They are always hiring people, because they are always firing people for stupid ridiculous things. The manager will come up with fake things if you get on her bad side, especially if you are Caucasian. My advice to white girls – don’t do it. It’s simply not worth putting years of hard work into a dead end job to get fired over bs. I know the economy is bad, but it’s not worth accepting a job will you will ultimately be unappreciated, over worked and ultimately fired. Half the people there are temp workers w/o any benefits. The turnover is high and the talk is cheap.

review_title: A good place to work but hard for people who have been here a while to live through difficult but necessary changes
pros: Variety of case mix, strong standing in the community, great reputation and strives to live up to it
cons: Poor leadership in past created some challenging situations that current leadership is now trying to correct.  Time will tell if they can make the needed changes without losing valuable staff.

job_title: Patient Services Coordinator in Seattle, WA
pros: Great growth opportunities within SMG and SMC. As long as you get to know the right people, moving up isn't very difficult. Offers training classes and shadowing desired positions if asked. Quarterly bonuses if certain SMG/SMC goals are met. Annual cost of living and merit increases.
cons: Management constantly pushing for more from providers and staff. It takes forever for positions to get approved through the board, even to replace existing positions, leaving current employees with stressful amount of work. Working extremely hard doesn't get noticed unless you "suck-up" to management.

job_title: I 0 FTE MDT in Issaquah, WA
pros: Good environment, good people, and very patient focused. This job honed in skills I had thought I mastered before and they helped put me through school so I really only have positives on the large scale to say about my employment.
cons: Management and the union spend too much time and money fighting each other causing contention and leaving wallets thin instead of full. Occasionally people in the service departments get treated as inferior and not worth being heard. This is typical of newer fresh out of collage nurses and doctors but some of the third and fourth decade employees are unbending.

pros: There are some great people to work with but mostly people aren't friendly. I think the best perk was the parking pass to be honest.
cons: Stressful and under paid. This is specifically for CBSI of course. You can't work over 40 hours or you will get written up for 'theft of time' . Yeah go ahead and try and make sense of that! The workload they give you can't be done in 40 hours as a medical assistant. It's like the people who slacked off and didn't care got more respect. Horrible company to work for. You can get demoted if one person above you isn't fond of you. Raises and promotions given to people who are friends with management. My friend worked there 10 years and was demoted!

review_title: Swedish Edmonds Pharmacy; small hospital, BIG disappointment!
job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Edmonds, WA
pros: The location eliminated my commute. The insurance benefits are great. The training at the First Hill campus was very helpful. You definitely notice a difference in that First Hill is a lot more organized, supportive, positive, and welcoming than Edmonds.
cons: The environment is not conducive to learning, questions are not encouraged and are viewed as if you are challenging their processes. There are very few reference materials, especially in the way of expiration dating. There are difficult personalities and you'll feel caught in the middle of their varying opinions and power struggles. The lack of teamwork between the evening and night shifts was like nothing I've ever seen before. The conflicting information from co-workers and management will leave you extremely frustrated. Don't expect any support from leadership. Your concerns will not be addressed. They would rather terminate you.

pros: People working there are really dedicated, individual acts of great kindness and caring. Swedish listened to staff and was responsive to challenges. Now unsupported by a "ready...fire...aim" management
cons: Poor management structure, takeover by Providence changed culture from Nordstrom's to Walmart. Catholic Provbot culture pervades what was a great place to work. Unethical decision making, like hiring and then laying people off 2 weeks later, does not inspire confidence. Cost cutting measures gut the integrity of the organization.

job_title: Patient Safety Officer in Seattle, WA
pros: The director/VP I reported to were incredible, the quality dept. staff were talented, driven and personable and the salary was appropriate.
cons: The culture and executive leadership was unpredictable/ unreliable. There was a high degree of turnover due to frustration with the organization and the inability to effect change. The political climate was the worst I have experienced and was influenced, in part, by the Providence affiliation.

pros: good money good benefits time off .Union. some coworkers are great to work with
cons: problems with communication through upper management, more concerned about money less concerned about the important issues. seem to pay attention to petty complaints from co workers about coworkes.  senior workers  on people for petty issues that do not affect patient care. some employees think they're too big to help with patient care when they have the qualifications to be part of the team instead they just watch over. infection control not being followed by the book,  lots of negative talk and gossip.

pros: Money and people. The benefits are great, I like most of my coworkers, and they pay well.
cons: Now owned by Providence which is very bottom line, and it shows. Morale is down. Management makes it very obvious that it is all about what they say. And infighting between departments is the worst I've seen anywhere.

pros: I've never had a more flexible job. The work is very cyclical but there are times you could finish everything you needed to do in 6 hours. The employees here are truly stellar for the most part and are really hard workers.
cons: Management is extremely suspicious of everyone and really abuses some of their top workers. It's an environment of fear and the ones who last led have learned to stay to themselves out of view. It's truly sad that this is a continuing problem here that seems to never be dealt with.

review_title: Not just a job, but a career
pros:
This place is amazing. I've worked many different places and I can honestly say I've never found a job that values your opinions, career aspirations, and personal life (hello work/life balance!!!). Throughout the organization, there is a sense of community and equality where everyone's voice matters and that allows for you to expand your career in ways you never thought possible.

On top of everything else, the organization is committed to patient safety, customer service and innovation. There are so many health organizations in Seattle and I feel confident that this is the top.
cons: I really can't think of one.

job_title: Patient Services Coordinator in Redmond, WA
pros: Good opportunity to grow within the company internally (though not necessarily within a specific clinic). Welcoming and friendly environment; HR comes around several times a year to check in on clinic processes/employee satisfaction levels.
cons: Very short-staffed; large amount of turnover. 10-hour shifts (which isn't bad unless you have to take on a lot of overtime due to being called in for the clinic being short-staffed, etc.). A bit underpaid for how much work with insurance, etc. is happening.

job_title: Inpatient Mental Health RN (Per Diem) in Edmonds, WA
pros: I worked as a per diem psych RN at Stevens when they were bought out by Swedish (2010-2011). I had a great experience. They dedicated a lot of time and effort to making sure we were oriented well, and they appeared to prioritize staff and patient safety. I liked the fact that they had on-site security. I loved the unit set up (actually two units) - one very restrictive with a high nurse-patient ratio (usually around 1:3), and then patients could "graduate" to a less-restrictive unit. Great co-workers, too!
cons: My unit management was just okay. They appeared to have little experience in the field and were rarely present on days when I was working.

review_title: Worst job experience of my life
pros:
Good wages, due only to union pressure. 
Decent benefits, but could be better considering it is a hospital after all.
cons:
This place is run by incompetent workers who have been promoted to managers solely on seniority and not based on any experience or leadership skills. This results in people who mistreat their employees and "boss them around".
If it weren't for the unions in the hospital the work conditions would be even more deplorable for those in the lower-end jobs such kitchen, cleaning and possibly nurses and nurses' assistants.
After what I've witnessed as an employee I will not even go there as a patient.

review_title: You may wear a lot of hats, but it will be interesting
pros: Excellent benefits, immediate supervisor was great, plenty of flexibility with working from home when duties/COVIDocalypse allowed. The companies senior leadership seems noticeably more transparent with employees than most private health companies.
cons: More frequent and significant changes than is typical as the company continues to integrate with Providence.  This position may stop existing as the Providence CIS teams take over more of the Epic systems training. Also, it's private healthcare, so there are too many instances which felt like profit was being prioritized over optimal patient care. Hopefully we get a single-payer option soon and companies are brought more to heel soon so this won't be an issue.

pros: Excellent benefits & Great Reuptation in the community
cons: Its a very management heavy organization. Directors are constantly on email communications about lower level communication. If you hire someone to do a job shouldnt they be allowed/permitted to do their job? A open "policy" that if you know the CEO you can get a job. I worked next to an employee for almost a year before leaving, and she openly let everyone know she not only got her job because she knew the VP (our CEO) but she was allowed to chose which opportunity she wanted. She had no past exp, I came here with 12 yrs. She made more than me. Very sad indeed.

job_title: Patient Services Coordinator II Lead in Seattle, WA
pros:
Higher than usual Pay
Carpooling discounts on parking
Variety of jobs to choose from
Able to transfer to other departments
cons:
SMC/Providence is $$ driven
HIGH parking cost for ALL NON LICENSED caregivers. RNs, MDs and other Licensed caregivers frequently have their parking paid for.
Raises are very low and infrequent
No formal reward system besides an online compliment system
Clinic Volumes are more important than 'Extraordinary Caring'
If you file a complaint with HR, they will view the whistle-blower as the one who is problematic
Providers are often Conservative and express homophobic and sexist views
Organization is top heavy, most managers will not listen to their front line staff

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Mill Creek, WA
pros: New Starbucks that provides food because cafeteria has limited hours.  Pay is not bad.  Union contract is new.  New main lobby
cons: Staff are unwelcoming, unfriendly rude and back stabbing.  The nursing staff eat both their young and old.  The PACU is unmanaged and  this allows poor behavior  by some of the nurses toward others. There are cliques in both OR and PACU. The  management is aware of the issue but nothing is done.

review_title: Great team of therapists who provide compassionate care. Limited opportunity for growth.
pros: Swedish has a wonderful team of therapists. They deliver excellent care that is relevant and compassionate. We look out for each other and people always lend a hand to make sure our patients are seen. Our department has CD's available to assist with continuing Ed and management now allows us a paid day off to take a continuing Ed course (paid for). We used to have to use our own PTO. For the most part, time off is granted but it's much harder to get time off around holidays.
cons: The pay is NOT competitive and the annual increases do NOT reflect that your work is valued despite being told in your performance review that you do wonderful work and that management is happy to have you on the team. There is no opportunity in the therapy department for professional advancement. You are either a therapist or in management. Without a path to grow professionally, the long-term path looks uninspiring punctuated by a flat salary. This may explain the high turnover in our department not to mention the high turnover in the nursing departments. There is a sense of favoritism in our department between management and certain therapists. Also there is no way other than the satisfaction survey to really give input about manager performance. There was one opportunity to give a peer review of my supervisor, but it was not anonymous. The management team seems to be a clique of sorts and I feel any professional critique would be shared with the writer attributed. Morale is low especially after recent performance reviews. Many therapists are now keeping their eyes open for employment opportunities elsewhere. Low salary is the key driver for this.

pros: With the new, prominent support of senior leadership to research, I look forward to a growing environment and more job security without having to continually justify my position and my value to the organization. Benefits were fantastic when I started, but changes in benefits since the affiliation have decreased their value to employees, notably changes in health insurance, raises dependent on organizational financial health, raises for all employees occurring at the same time and being cost of living based rather than on employees' anniversaries, etc. Even with those changes, benefits are still good and better than other organizations.
cons: I have had extreme difficulty in my attempts to further develop my skills, stay current in my field, and grow within the organization. Despite a strong work ethic, proven leadership, and extensive knowledge in my field and areas that impact it, I continually take on more tasks, both on my own and at the request of my boss, without promotion and/or compensation. Further, my department has had a history of tension and issues amongst coworkers which had led to a sometimes unenjoyable team environment. Thankfully, I have never personally had these issues, but then tensions between others has given rise to a team that isn't always cohesive.

pros: Large hospital so they have a lot of resources and opportunities for growth. Nursing staff are unionized which helps with staffing and making sure we have benefits.
cons: It's the only hospital I've worked at but I hear there's not a lot of autonomy compared to other hospitals. Also we are working without a contract at present. This is the first time the union has bargained since Providence took over Swedish--so far our benefits aren't what they used to be but we are all fighting to change that!

job_title: RN Care Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: Most of my colleagues are great, hard-working, compassionate people.
cons: I felt like management had no clue what was going on, and didn't necessarily care to find out.  This contributed to a mass exodus in my department, which only made things harder, increasing the workload  and burnout.

pros: Pay is comparable to Seattle metro area. PTO accrues rapidly if you don't make every weekend three days long. Health insurance is reasonably priced.
cons: The work is repetitive, and often feels like an uphill battle. Management changes tech every couple of years with programs that either conflict with each other or don't work for a company of this size. Promotions are reserved for smoking buddies. The managers are all friends and if you cross one, you cross them all.

pros: The benefits are amazing. You get quarterly bonuses which is based on the revenue of your clinic. You get up to two weeks paid vacation. Great health insurance plans! (I only paid $6 a month for just me.) Plenty of oppotunity especially to apply internally.
cons: Some clinics are better to work at than others. I started out at heart and vascular which had a high school esque vibe. By that I mean people are in there own cliques, there's tons of gossip, and the clinic ops at the time had her favorites.

pros: great environment to work in that provides many learning opportunities in healthcare. I would certainly return to work for them if needed. Great team facilitated lab and room for growth!
cons: typical hospital working environment. I cannot think of many cons at all. I enjoyed where I worked and would recommend this facility to anyone, especially the motivated!

job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: They let you use your PTO whenever you need too.
cons: A lot of secretive plans being made, that are obvious to the employees. Managment is not focused on patient care rather more for money. Very disappointed on what I have seen within Swedish. The people who make it far within the company are the ones who lose their integrity and become greedy. Within my specific clinics flexibility and advancement plans are not an option for an MA. MAs treated as if they are not an important part of the team.

pros: I appreciate the ever improving atmosphere of this company.  The change can be overwhelming at times, but they are moving in the right direction for a hospital and doing amazing things on a day to day basis.  They ask a lot of each of their employees, but it's for the right reasons.
cons: Can be overwhelming and daunting, but it is always for reasons that I can easily get behind and support.

pros: I have to chose a pro?
cons: This has to be the worst place in health care I have ever worked. People act ghetto to be cool. I’ve never seen so many nurses and doctors speak in ebonics in order to act cool and fit in. It is run rampant by lazy employees who work the clock. Bullying is not only regular, the bystander effect is appalling. I have watched charge nurses and doctors just sit back and watch while people are picked on for being white. I have never seen reverse racism like this in my life, among all places in an emergency room. It is an embarrassment.

review_title: Great place for care, hard to work for
pros: Lots of opportunity for growth. They do favor internal hires for new roles being built out so that's a plus once you're in the door. Swedish does have some of the best care in the PNW. Really innovative and progressive.
cons: Many layers of middle management. Hard to actually get your voice heard of you're not within the management structure. People are kept in boxes - not much room for creativity.

review_title: Good skill building, but ultimately a burn out
job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Seattle, WA
pros:
Ok benefits
Great , very hard working staff
Some very skilled providers
cons:
MANAGEMENT are all about saving money, which means terrible staffing and very slow to hire new staff. = Burnout

The net effect is that there are tons of new nurses with less skill, because the wise ones are getting the heck out!

review_title: No career advancement; great stepping stone
pros:
lots of overtime
diverse work environment
great stepping stone to learn and apply somewhere else
cons:
no opportunity to advance
no set of standards, each Swedish location does things differently
lack of involvement from supervisor
employees and employer would prefer you to email your complaint instead of talking to the other person about it.
lots of gossip and favortism

pros: The benefit package was okay except the bus passes could be cheaper. There is no standardization between clinics. Nurses should have more training and be a resource for the clinic. Nursing supervisors should not ask one medical assistant on how to discipline  another medical assistant.
cons: Clinic administers are not qualified for the positions. Favoritism and racism are rampant. Evaluations are vetted by HR before they are discussed with the employees. This sends the message that no matter what, management is always right. Complaints from employees are dismissed by management.

pros: Only pro is that I worked with great nurses who understood the poor working conditions and were willing to help even when they were swamped and drowning.
cons: Nurses are not valued. Most of staff is new grads because experienced nurses leave for better working conditions. Management cares more about better scores than actually supplying the staff to alleviate the high workload of all staff. More and more responsibilities being added to nurses with budget cuts. Will never seek employment here or at any HCA facility.

review_title: Stevens Hospital... an up and coming employer of choice!
pros:
Great teamwork
Sense of fun
Increased accountability
Less "dead weight" on the team
Greater sense of urgency surrounding critical issues
Increased support from senior leadership
Performance based merit increases
Great new talent from out of state
Affiliating with Swedish Medical Center
cons:
While accountability is on the upswing ownership of issues at an analytical level leaves a lot to be desired
Grooming habits and professional appearance
Odor in some office spaces
Lots of time off without notice (dependability)

review_title: Solid organization leading healthcare, good opportunities
pros: Lots of variety in opportunities - many campuses, environments, departments. This is a great place to grow a career or have a job while you're raising a family or doing something else. Good benefits, good management, people trying to do their best in a complex industry.
cons: Downtown commute can be a bear but that's a choice one makes to work for a great organization.

pros:
- great knowledgeable ER Team!
- room to learn and grow with online/hands on classes
- level 2 ER so don't expect code blues and GSW but do expect to learn basic care techniques 
- Union.
cons:
- communication could be better
- they were just taken over by providence but remain a separate organization. If  Providence had it there way they would remove the union,  lower employee wages, increase number of Pt to providers and give you minimal healthcare. Be glad we are in a union.

job_title: Patient Services Coordinator in Seattle, WA
pros: Generally helpful coworkers, interesting pace of work, and relatively good salary and benefits. This position does not require much previous experience, so it is good for someone with little experience in the medical field, though of course more precious experience would make it easier.
cons: Often stressful, very much requires the ability to multitask and take note of tasks, as often things can get lost in a hectic moment. Office environments can sometimes be catty and tricky, but that can happen anywhere

pros: Swedish has excellent benefits and there is opportunity for growth. There has been changes throughout the years but the goal still remains to provide the best quality care for patients
cons: There’s really no downside to working at Swedish. It is what you make for yourself. The only thing would be the rising costs of medical benefits but that is inevitable

pros: I chose to work at Swedish because of the relocation benefits, multiple scheduling options, multiple locations to choose from, beautiful commute
cons: While the commute is lovely it can be time consuming and if you live on the other side of the water you're stuck dealing with rigid ferry schedules to make your shift work.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Seattle, WA
pros:
Benefits for part and full time employment 
Orca Card for $10/mo 
Passport discounts
1 hour PTO for 10 hours worked
cons:
You have to pay for parking
The health plans could be better 
There are really no educational benefits. There's something for RN to BSN but outside of that its extremely limited.
Getting in touch with HR is difficult.
Constant Layoffs/downsizing

review_title: Waiting for the other shoe to drop.
pros: Flexible work hours. Decent benefits. Union representation.
cons: Without the Union looking out for me and fighting to keep my benefits, I would probably be out of a job altogether. Upper management gets all the perks while the workers get put under more and more pressure. My job satisfaction has continued to diminish over the years of working here, instead of getting better.

pros: Great staff and providers. Great benefits with compensation
cons: High turnover.  Medical Assistants work well below scope of practice. A lot of the positions work more like reception rather than Medical Assistants. Staffing is always too low. Poor organization

review_title: Experience working at Swedish Medical Center
job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: Supportive and friendly staff + management who care about the best interest of their patients, prioritizing safety, and working as a team. Competitive pay and benefits as well. Very rewarding careers and opportunity to grow. I always felt supported by those I worked with, including my manager.
cons: Similar downsides of working in any field of healthcare, can be fast paced and long work hours.

review_title: Great doctors, not so great management
pros: Some of the best doctors to work with, most nurses and MA's were nice and willing to train, good benefits and pay compared to others.
cons: Extreme micro management, high office politics, favoritism with no intervention from HR. Bullying in the workplace. No paid parking for newer employees.

job_title: Patient Care Services in Seattle, WA
pros: Nothing - the benefits are awful and all locationsa re going to6 day work weeks with nights and weekends. The pay is awful and people are leaving in droves.
cons:
Constant turnover at all levels including doctors
Management with NO medical background
Discriminatory in thier HR practices
Pateint care has declined quickly - pateints are fleeing for University Of Washington 
Senior & Corporate Management Teams have also left for U of W

pros: Swedish paid for me to move to Seattle. I can't think of any other pro.
cons: When I started at Swedish the OR Manager was new, the educator was new and the OR is 65% travelers. This place is a horrible mess.

pros: Swedish is an inspiring environment most days. The work is Innovative, a willingness to take risks, and day in/out you'll work with intelligent professionals
cons: It's unavoidable given the current disruption in the healthcare market but it is not uncommon for key projects to stall. Many are abandoned for 'the next best thing' and not hardwired only to be revived in the future.

pros: This organization claims to be the Cadillac of healthcare- they have beautifully renovated buildings and a lot of specialties focusing on patient care.great doctors
cons: Untrained  management teams. A lot of politics.  Nepotism at the work place and rules only apply to everyone except upper management.

pros: I have nothing nice to say about Swedish. I now live in another state and could not be happier
cons: I was told they saw no point in my position. I had to turn my manager into risk management. The supervisor belittles people behind their back. I reported an employee for threats. Management told me I had to earn his trust back. We went from serving 70-100 patients a day to 15. The patients cannot stand the new management. The hospital tried to give us  catastrophic insurance . In other word, get hit by a bus you’re covered. Catch the flu, to bad

pros: Good entry salary, but then freezes pretty much
cons:
Another round of layoffs and mass department closing 
550 + losing jobs 
Great long term employees leaving can get perfect reviews for years on end and tomorrow, sorry position eliminated
Every two years layoffs are eminent at holiday time

pros: Awesome providers, great access to healthcare, some brilliant minds among your coworkers.
cons:
Career Development is nil. There is much chatter about it, but no actual planning. 
It is difficult to receive recognition from Management, as they are keen on getting it themselves
Lack of cohesion in rolling out projects.

review_title: Overall, nice workload. Overall nice place to work.
job_title: Patient Financial Counselor in Seattle, WA
pros: For the most part management is pretty flexible with this particular position. You don't have to worry about micromanagement. Other colleagues are always there to help.
cons: Working directly in clinics as a billing advocate has its challenges. Some clinic administrators aren't as professional & kind to say the least. You report to billing however you work directly with the clinic & depending on the clinic, you could be in a tough spot- between clinch & billing department.

review_title: A place where people have heart
pros: Great benefits... great coworkers...all jobs support saving lives so it's fulfilling.
cons: Big organization. Hard to find employee parking in some locations. A lot of management change at the very top.  Satisfaction seemed very tied to who your VP/C level was.  New CEO is excellent and brought organization into profitability in a short time.

review_title: Do yourself a favor and STAY AWAY.
pros: Health benefits, most of the campuses are nice and I enjoyed all the flowers/plants. Also occasional get togethers with all staff.
cons: No support from management, lack of kindness, no growth opportunities, little pay for what the work is, everyone hates their job and management. Overall, extremely negative environment. Manager didn’t even know my daily roles. Was doing way more than what I was hired on for.

review_title: Struggling a bit, but trying hard
pros: Good staff, lots of training opportunities
cons: Slowly losing it's advantages- people are leaving quickly d/t high workloads and unrealistic expectations.

review_title: Overall, a decent place to work
job_title: Clinical Social Worker in Seattle, WA
pros:
1. Very good pay for social workers
2. A very well-regarded healthcare system
3. A variety of settings in which to work
4. Professional atmosphere
cons:
1. Frequent reorganization of departments
2. Lack of opportunities for advancement for social workers
3. Not many full-time positions

pros: Good pay compared to comparable jobs in Seattle.  Supportive manager, great team, support from management.  Nice to work with high-quality care providers who are tops in their field.
cons: short-staffed for patient load - would be able to provide better care to more people with more staff. no compensation for continuing ed.

pros: Great colleagues (though the good ones are leaving in droves)
cons:
Deteriorating management.  Focus away from provider autonomy and patient care towards assembly line type expectations and placing non clinicians in key management roles.  
Leadership evolving into an "old boys club" with obvious attempts to eliminate women in positions of strength.  
Changing compensation plan sold as adding value/quality to patients, but in reality, shifting finances from primary care to specialists.

pros: Our team In the ED is very close we work very well together ,
cons: Management is rarely present during the shifts . Only when we are saturated and on diversion.

review_title: As an Insurance Representative II I lost myself, I was singled out and degraded almost daily.
pros: My previous position & Boss were Amazing!! I was treated with respect and I felt very valuable, I trained ppl and my production was on point if not higher.
cons: Moving to the "Dark side" where everyone feel less but no one will speak up because they will make you feel like nothing and have the emotion of how dare you... Sad. Too many great ppl have left for this reason.

review_title: Needs Help in the HR Department
job_title: Patient Service Representative in Redmond, WA
pros: Swedish does have a Great Orientation Program. Very organized and thorough.
cons: The human resources department (especially through Providence) does not follow through or help its employees lower level employees. Especially when it comes to dealing with problems caused by management. There is a severe lack of support for employees when it comes to these issues.

job_title: Nursing Administrative Supervisor/RN Case Manager in Edmonds, WA
pros: Excellent staff with a lot of good people.
cons: Extremely poor schedule with a manager that had no desire to change and was a bully. Swedish itself is very unstable with regular layoffs . In my seven years there were three major layoffs. These occur with no planning or though about the consequences  or how the jobs done by those eliminated will be carried out. Seniority means little and as you climb in the pay scale the target on your back gets larger.

pros: Various different specialties, so you will find one that interests you, the option to be trained is there. You will have no lack of work.
cons: Some of the Coding Consultants are malicious in the way that they  train. The lack of information they provide coupled with the disinformation, or malicious information will set you to fail.  Beware of "touch base" meetings set with no agenda. It never is a good thing.

review_title: Good frontline people, poor engagement from higher administration
job_title: Registered Nurse, Critical Care in Seattle, WA

cons: Lack of support and engagement from higher administration. Appears to always be budget driven with lack of support for long-term sustainability

review_title: In the 10 years I've been with Swedish, I've had a lot of ups and a few downs. But if I had to do it again I would!

cons: Commuting on the ferries to and from work takes a lot more out of me than it did a decade ago.

cons: Don't know how to do finances always laying people off .  Senior management is kingdom builders and care more about status than what is going on!

cons: Due to staffing crunches, difficult to find work/life balance. Clinical administrator attends a lot of meetings outside the office, leaving a lot of the responsibility falling on the clinic op's position.

-PTO
